ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read More-igami, we talked about the shapes we saw in the pictures.

In this activity, I will choose a card that shows a shape. I will put the card behind my back, and I will give you hints about the mystery shape. You will guess the shape! You can also ask me questions, if you need more information.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Place the Activity Cards picture-side down in a pile on the table. Have children sit across the table from you, making sure they cannot see the Activity Cards you pull.

Ask Choose the first Activity Card. Look at the shape on it, then hold the card behind your back. Give children one clue as to what shape it is. For example: I am holding a shape with straight sides. Do you know what shape this is? Guide children to guess the shape or ask for more clues. Continue to give children clues (This shape has three sides) until they are able to guess the shape correctly.
Extend When children have correctly guessed the shape, show them the card. Ask, What else do you know about this shape?
Repeat Continue the activity using the other Activity Cards. When you reach a double, give different clues. For example: I am holding a shape you might see in the wheel of a car.
Talk About Shapes Talk about the shapes children guessed. Which shapes were easy to guess? Which shapes were hard to guess? What clues were the most helpful to you?

Place Pattern Blocks and/or cut-out shapes on the table that represent each possible shape (square, circle, triangle, rectangle). As you describe each card, encourage children to look at the shapes on the table, and point to and name the one that matches your description.

Have children work with partners. Have Partner A pull an Activity Card and give clues about the shape on the card. Partner B guesses the shape and confirms by looking at the card. Repeat with Partner B giving the clues and Partner A guessing the shapes.

Use Pattern Blocks and other manipulatives to reinforce the terms square, rectangle, circle, and triangle before having children participate in the activity. When you discuss properties of shapes, use your hands to give visual cues (hold up three fingers for three sides, hold your hands straight to show straight sides, etc.).

To lessen distractors in the room, encourage children to close their eyes as they listen to you describe each shape. You may also provide a ball or other soft object for children to squeeze to help them focus.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need markers, many square pieces of paper for each child to fold, and pages 32–33 of More-igami. You may wish to make a copy of these pages for easier reference.

Connect to Large Group When we read More-igami, we saw Joey make an origami crane! In the back of the book, there are directions to create a different origami animal—a ladybug! Show children pages 32–33 of More-igami.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: We are going to follow the directions to make an origami ladybug. I will show each step first, then you will try to copy my folds. Don’t worry if you make a mistake—it’s more important to practice and keep going than to be perfect!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Give each child a square piece of paper, and take one for yourself. Place extra squares in the pile in the center of the table, and let children know they can take another piece if they want to start over. Ask, What shape is the piece of paper now?
Fold Follow the first step of the directions, carefully folding your square in half to make a triangle. Guide children to fold their own paper the same way, and ask, What shape is this?

Repeat Continue to follow the directions, guiding children to copy each step after you have shown how to do it. Ask about the paper’s shape each time you make a new fold or flip. Continue until the ladybug is complete.
Talk About Origami Congratulate children on having created origami! Discuss what was easy and difficult, reinforcing that it takes practice to become skilled at any task.
Sit next to children as they create each fold, repeating your own fold multiple times while also repeating the directions. If necessary, help children fold their pieces of paper as directed.
Give children a new piece of paper. Challenge them to fold it into different shapes: a triangle, a rectangle, and a smaller square.

Review key vocabulary, such as ladybug, fold, and practice. Use sentence clozes to help children describe the shapes they see, and make sure that all children can clearly see the folds you are making in your paper.

Creating origami is a fine-motor skill, but you can incorporate gross motor by having children show the shapes they see in each fold with their arms. Encourage children to trace a big square in the air using both hands, or make a triangle with their arms over their heads.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need several two-dimensional shapes (triangle, circle, rectangle, square) and several three-dimensional objects (ball, cube, can, and pyramid). You will also need a bag for children to draw the objects from.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read More-igami, we talked about shapes that are flat and shapes that are not flat.
In this activity, each of you will pull a shape from this bag. You will say what shape it is, and share how you know. Then, you will sort the shapes into two piles: flat and not flat.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Draw Place all of the two- and three-dimensional objects in the bag. Have the first child reach in and pull out an object. Ask, What shape do you have? How do you know? Encourage the child to describe the attributes of the shape.
Sort Ask the child to place the object into one of two piles: flat or not flat. Provide assistance as needed.
Repeat Have other children draw and sort objects from the bag, until all children have had a turn. Play again if time permits.

Talk About Sorting Lay all of the objects on the table and encourage children to explore them. Ask, What makes an object flat or not flat? Are there other flat items in the room that are these shapes? Are there other not-flat objects in the room that match the ones we looked at today?
Model choosing an object and describing it. For example: This object is round. It has no sides or corners. When I hold it in both hands, my hands don’t touch. It is not flat. That makes it a ball.

Challenge children to close their eyes as they reach into the bag and try to figure out what shape or object they are holding without looking. Encourage them to feel each side and first say whether the object is flat or not before guessing the shape or object.

Review key vocabulary, specifically three-dimensional shapes: cube, ball, pyramid, and can. Encourage children to use hand motions as they describe the shape or object they choose, and provide sentence clozes as necessary.

If possible, find objects that are a similar color, or do not have bright colors. Some children may find it difficult to process many bright colors at once, and may have trouble deciding the shape of something multicolored. You may also provide gloves for children who may be nervous to put their hands in the bag without knowing what they will be touching.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need modeling dough or clay. You can make your own, or use commercial dough. Alternatively, use Connecting Cubes or drawing materials to draw instead of sculpt. You will also need crayons, a large piece of paper, and sticky notes.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read A Horse, of Course, we talked about creating a horse out of clay.
In this activity, you will sculpt and mold something new! You will each use modeling clay to create whatever you like. After, we will sort your creations into groups and make a graph.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Create Give each child a chunk of modeling clay, and ask them to sculpt or mold whatever they want. Encourage children to be creative!

Sort Once children have finished their creations, ask them to describe what they created. Guide children to sort their creations into two groups. Encourage them to decide what the two groups could be, or guide them to sort into animal and non-animal.

Graph Once all creations have been sorted, work with children to create a bar graph representing the two groups. Ask children to write their name on a sticky note and place it in the corresponding column.

Talk About Graphs Talk about the sculptures children created and the categories they graphed. Which shapes do you see in the art you created? Which type of creature was created the most: animal or non-animal? Why do you think that is? How can you tell which group had the most objects from the graph?
Create your own artwork, and model sorting it into a category: I made a cat with long whiskers. A cat is an animal, so I will place it in the animal group. Now there is one animal creation.
Have children sort their creations in more than one way (by category, by size, by shapes used, etc.). Create a bar graph for each version.

Review key vocabulary such as sculpt, mold, and creation. Point to objects in the room as you discuss the categories of art (a stuffed animal, a classmate, a plant, a chair) and encourage children to count the creations in each category using their fingers or other manipulatives.

Encourage children to use tools to help them sculpt their art, such as pencils, tweezers, plastic cutlery—anything you can turn into a sculpting tool. Guide children to focus on one or two small details in their creation.
